# Chapter 1: Review of classical inference

## Distributions

â€¢ The term "distribution" will be used a lot.

â€¢ A distribution gives the values a variable takes on, and how often it takes them on.

â€¢ Examples: normal distribution, uniform distribution, distribution of exam scores, distribution of heights...

## Commonly used statistics

### Mean

â€¢ Mean and median identify the center of a data set or distribution.

â€¢ The mean of a variable $X$ is denoted $\bar{X}$.

â€¢ To calculate the mean of a data set, add up all the values of a variable and divide by how many there are.

$$
\bar{X} = \frac{\sum^n_{i=1}x_i}{n}
$$

### Median

â€¢ Median is the "middle" number in a data set. To find the median, put the data values in order from smallest to largest, and identify the number in the middle.

â€¢ If there are an even number of data points, the median is the average of the middle two numbers:

![](images/Mod1_1.png){fig-align="center" width="338"}

### Mean vs. Median

â€¢ In statistical inference (the process of generalizing from sample to population), we most often draw inference on the population mean.

â€¢ Sometimes, though, the median is a more sensible statistic than the mean.

â€¢ This is usually the case when we are studying a "skewed" distribution.

â€¢ Skewed distributions are distributions that take on values that are extreme (or outlying) values.

â€¢ Example: income. Most households have incomes between \$20,000/yr and \$100,000/yr. A handful of households have incomes in the millions or billions of dollars per year.

â€¢ The mean is affected by outliers. The median is not. This is why we often hear about "median household income" rather than "mean household income".

### Variance and standard deviation

â€¢ The center of a distribution is quantified by the mean or the median.

â€¢ The variability (i.e. spread) of a distribution is quantified by the standard deviation, which is closely related to the variance.

â€¢ The variance of a distribution or data set is denoted $s^2$:

$$
s^2 = \frac{\sum^n_{i=1}(x_i - \bar{x})^2}{n-1}
$$

â€¢ The standard deviation is simply the square root of the variance

$$
s = \sqrt{\frac{\sum^n_{i=1}(x_i - \bar{x})^2}{n-1}}
$$

â€¢ Think of this as the "standard" amount by which values deviate from their mean.

â€¢ We will most often look at standard deviation, because it is the more interpretable of the two statistics. It is in the same units as the original variable.

### The correlation coefficient

â€¢ The correlation coefficient, ğ‘Ÿ, quantifies the extent to which two variables (call them X and Y) move together:

$$
r = (\frac{1}{n-1})\sum^n_{i=1}\frac{(x_i - \bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{s_xs_y} = (\frac{1}{n-1})\sum^n_{i=1}z_{x_i}z_{y_i}
$$

â€¢ Don't worry too much about the formula. The most important things to know are:

â€¢ When two variables move in the opposite direction (i.e. when one gets bigger, the other gets smaller), $r$ is negative.

â€¢ When they move in the same direction, $r$ is positive.

â€¢ $r = 0$ means no correlation. $r =1$ means perfect positive correlation. $r = -1$ means perfect negative correlation.

## Statistics and parameters

â€¢ A statistic is any value calculated from data.

â€¢ A parameter is any value pertaining to a population.

â€¢ The values of unknown parameters are "estimated" using statistics.

â€¢ Example: a sample mean can be used to estimate a population mean. i.e. $\bar{X}$ estimates $\mu$.

## Sampling distributions

â€¢ A sampling distribution is the distribution of values a statistic takes on, under repeated sampling.

â€¢ For example, the Central Limit Theorem states that the sampling distribution of $\bar{X}$ will be normal, so long as the sample size ($n$) is large enough.

â€¢ Sampling distributions are important because most methods used in statistical inference invoke long run frequency properties.

â€¢ Example: if the sampling distribution of $\bar{X}$ is not very spread out, then the value of $\bar{X}$ should not change much if we take a new sample.

### Standard error

â€¢ Standard error is the standard deviation of a sampling distribution.

â€¢ In other words, it is the amount of variability in the values a statistic takes on under repeated sampling.

â€¢ So, if a statistic we calculate has a small standard error, we can infer that the value of that statistic is close to the value of the population parameter it is estimating. If it has a large standard error, its value might be very far away from the value of the parameter.

â€¢ Example: the standard error of $\bar{X}$ is $\frac{s}{\sqrt{n}}$ i.e. $s_{\bar{X}} = \frac{s}{\sqrt{n}}$

### Sampling dist. and standard error, visually

â€¢ On Canvas there is a Central Limit Theorem simulator.

â€¢ When the sample size is large, the distribution of the sample mean is not very spread out. In other words, its standard error is small.

â€¢ When the sample size is small, the standard error is large.

## Confidence intervals

â€¢ A confidence interval ("CI") is an interval (i.e. a left endpoint and a right endpoint) constructed around a statistic, when that statistic is being treated as an estimate for the value of an unknown parameter.

â€¢ Typical confidence intervals are constructed by adding a "margin of error" to, and subtracting it from, an estimate:

â€¢ Typical margins of error are calculated by multiplying the standard error of the estimate by a "critical value". A critical value comes from a known distribution and is given by a confidence level.

â€¢ Example: a 95% CI for a population mean uses a critical value from the $t$ distribution (we won't cover why this is).

ğ¶ğ¼ ğ‘“ğ‘œğ‘Ÿ ğœ‡ = $\bar{x}$ Â± $ğ‘¡_{ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™}$ âˆ— $s_{\bar{x}}$

â€¢ As long as $n$ isn't tiny, the 95% critical value from a $t$ distribution is approximately 2:

ğ¶ğ¼ ğ‘“ğ‘œğ‘Ÿ ğœ‡ â‰ˆ $\bar{x}$ Â± $2$ âˆ— $s_{\bar{x}}$

â€¢ Confidence intervals should capture the unknown parameter value being estimated. The confidence level gives how often the interval captures the parameter under repeated sampling.

â€¢ Example: 95% of all 95% CIs for $\mu$ capture $\mu$ .

â€¢ The confidence level can also be thought of as the success rate of the method being used.

â€¢ So, 95% confidence intervals have a 95% success rate in capturing the value of the unknown parameter.

â€¢ Just as with sampling distributions, we are invoking repeated sampling here. We say that a 95% CI can be trusted because it is created using a method that would "work" 95% of the time, if we were to keep taking new samples and keep constructing 95% CIs.

## Confidence intervals quantify uncertainty

â€¢ The most important characteristic of a CI is its width.

â€¢ We are typically willing to believe that the unknown value of a parameter lies inside the confidence interval constructed from our data.

â€¢ If the confidence interval is wide, there is a lot of uncertainty as to the true value of the parameter.

â€¢ If the confidence interval is narrow, then our estimate for the value of the parameter is "precise", in that it shouldn't be wrong by much.

â€¢ CIs are narrow when the sample size is large and / or the standard deviation of our data is small.

â€¢ CIs are wide with the sample size is small and / or the standard deviation of our data is large.

â€¢ IMPORTANT: CIs, like all inferential statistical methods, are created under assumptions. We make distributional assumptions about our data (e.g. normality). We assume our statistic is an unbiased estimate of the parameter, i.e. it will not systematically differ from the parameter value under repeated sampling.

## Hypothesis testing

â€¢ Hypothesis testing is an inferential method in which a null hypothesis ($H_0$) is "tested" against. If the data are in strong enough disagreement with $H_0$ , then $H_0$ is rejected.

â€¢ $H_0$ typically represents the proposition that "there is nothing of interest at the population level", or "the proposed research hypothesis is not true".

â€¢ If $H_0$ is rejected, then the result of the test is described as "statistically significant".

â€¢ Example: if we have data from a controlled experiment in which $\mu_1$ represents the population mean for the control group and $\mu_2$ represents the population mean for the treatment group, then we might test against the null hypothesis:

$$
H_0: \mu_1 = \mu_2,\text{which is equivalent to }H_0: \mu_1 âˆ’ \mu_2 = 0
$$

â€¢ If we reject $H_0$, we say that the sample means, $\bar{x}_1$ and $\bar{x}_2$, are "significantly different". Or, equivalently, that $\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2$ is "signficantly different" from zero.

## The test statistic

â€¢ The strength of the evidence against $H_0$ is quantified by a "test statistic", from which a "p-value" is calculated.

â€¢ Test statistics are set up so that, the more the inconsistent the data are with $H_0$, the larger the test statistic will be.

â€¢ Example: when testing $H_0: \mu_1 âˆ’ \mu_2 = 0$, we use the test statistic:

$$
t = \frac{\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2}{s_{(\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2)}} = \frac{\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2}{\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2}{n_1} + \frac{s_2^2}{n_2}}} \text{(where } s_{(\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2)}\text{ is the standard error of }\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2)
$$

## The p-value

â€¢ The p-value is defined as the probability of getting a test statistic at least as large as the one calculated, if we assume $H_0$ is true.

â€¢ Visually, the p-value is the area in the tail of the sampling distribution of the test statistic under $H_0$

![](images/mod1_11.png){fig-align="center"}

â€¢ If the p-value is less than the "level of significance" ($\alpha$), then $H_0$ is rejected.

â€¢ By far the most typical level of significance is $\alpha = 0.05$

![](images/mod1_12.png){fig-align="center"}

### Interpreting "statistical significance"

â€¢ "Statistically significant" results are those that produce a small p-value.

â€¢ Small p-values result from data that would be unlikely to be obtained just by chance, if the null hypothesis were true.

â€¢ So, when you hear that results are "statistically significant", you can interpret this as meaning "the data we obtained don't look like the kind of data we'd expect to see just by chance".

### Cautions regarding "statistical significance"

â€¢ As with confidence intervals, hypothesis tests require assumptions.

â€¢ These will be covered in detail in the next module.

â€¢ The most important distinction to be made right now is the distinction between statistical significance and practical importance.

â€¢ Results can be statistically significant, but still seem weak or unimpressive by practical standards.

â€¢ Example: this is a statistically significant correlation:

![](images/mod1_13.png){fig-align="left" width="260"}

($r = 0.22$, p-value = 0.011)

â€¢ Example: this is a statistically significant difference in means:

![](images/mod1_14.png){fig-align="left" width="261"}

($\bar{x}_1 = 19.7$, $\bar{x}_2 = 22.7$, p-value = 0.0013)

â€¢ The use of hypothesis testing is controversial.

â€¢ I personally do not like hypothesis testing, and I think that statistical significance is usually uninteresting.

â€¢ We'll explore the debates surrounding statistical significance in module 2.

### Confidence intervals vs. p-values

â€¢ For now, we'll note that in many cases, confidence intervals can be used in place of p-values to perform a hypothesis test.

â€¢ If a 95% CI excludes the null value (typically zero), then $H_0$ is rejected at the $\alpha = 0.05$ level of significance.

â€¢ The advantage of using a confidence interval rather than a p-value is that it is easier to make sense out of, and it quantifies uncertainty: the wider the CI, the more uncertainty there is regarding the value of the unknown parameter.

95% CI for $\mu_1 - \mu_2: (-4.72,-1.19)$

â€¢ Note also that different CIs can correspond to the same p-value.
